_header: Early in the morning Jesu the Jews gin take
_description: The Hours of the Cross — 26 lines per hour; abcbdbebfgf followed by refrain of aabcbcdcecfgfhh

BodEngPoeta1.First Lines:
Erliche in þe morwenyngIhesu þe Jewes gunne
                    take…
BodEngPoeta1.Last Lines:
…Cristes passion heuene kyngBring us to blisse þat is
                    wiþ outen endyng. AMEN.
BodEngPoeta1.Facsimiles:
Doyle,  I. A.,
                        ed.  
             The Vernon Manuscript. A Facsimile of Bodleian Library, Oxford, MS Eng.
                poet.a.1,
          with an introduction by A. I. Doyle. Cambridge: D. S. Brewer, 1987. 
Scase,  Wendy,  and  Nick Kennedy, eds.  
             A facsimile edition of the Vernon manuscript: Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS. Eng. Poet. A. 1.
         Oxford: The Bodleian Library, 2011.
BodEngPoeta1.Editions:
Horstmann,  Carl,
                        ed.  
             The Minor Poems of the Vernon Manuscript, Part 1.
EETS
         o.s. 98 (1892; repr. 1973): 37-43.

CamGon175.First Lines:
Erly in a morewe þe iewes ihesu gan takeHys frendys & hys
                    dysciplis sone hym hadde fforsake…
CamGon175.Last Lines:
…Wiþ an O & an I ihesu off þy graceÞou
                    sende v vs here oure sustenaunse And in heuene a place
CamGon175.Note:
In this MS with addition of an ‘O’ and ‘I’
                    refrain; 6-line stanzas, aaaabb, sometimes written in half-lines.
CamGon175.Editions:
Heuser,  Wilhelm. 
             “With an O and an I.” 
             Anglia
         27 (1904): 283-319: 312-14.

BLAdd37787.First Lines:
Erlich in a morninge þe Jues Jhesu con takeHis frindes &
                    his disciples had him son for sake…
BLAdd37787.Last Lines:
And shewd him to mari madalyn to peter & mani moCrist honered
                    mot þu be þat bouhtest al þe world on a tree
BLAdd37787.Editions:
Baugh,  Nita Scudder. 
             A Worcestershire Miscellany, compiled by John
                    Northwood, c. 1400, edited from British Museum MS. Add.
                37,787.
         Philadelphia, 1956: 98.
